name: Kepler-226
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-226 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-226 is a star with 0.6950000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.8 times its radius. It is located 3288.11 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-226 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-226 b

Kepler-226 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.94 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-226.

The mass of Kepler-226 b is 2.74 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-226 b is 1.55 that of Earth. At 2.74 Earth masses, Kepler-226 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-226 c

Kepler-226 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.35 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-226.

The mass of Kepler-226 c is 6.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-226 c is 2.27 that of Earth. At 6.92 Earth masses, Kepler-226 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-226 d

Kepler-226 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.11 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-226.

The mass of Kepler-226 d is 1.56 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-226 d is 1.22 that of Earth. At 1.56 Earth masses, Kepler-226 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-226, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
